Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Early Psychosocial Intervention in Orthopaedic Trauma Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to integrative care (n=56) or usual care (n=56)

Participants.evidence: Participants were 112 orthopaedic trauma patients aged 18-85 years, excluding those with traumatic brain injury, communication barriers, or severe psychiatric conditions.

Intervention.evidence: Integrative care included usual trauma care plus psychosocial and movement strategies.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine if an early psychosocial intervention improves physical function outcomes compared to usual care.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was physical function, measured objectively (handgrip strength, active joint ROM, Lower Extremity Gain Scale) and subjectively (PROMIS®-PF, Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia) at baseline, 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were 112 orthopaedic trauma patients aged 18-85 years

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was per-protocol with 99 participants (integrative care n=50, usual care n=49).

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 6 months, no significant differences were found between groups in handgrip strength (right β=-0.0792, 95% CI -0.292 to 0.133, p=0.46; left β=-0.133, 95% CI -0.384 to 0.119, p=0.30) or Lower Extremity Gain Scale scores (β=-0.0303, 95% CI -0.191 to 0.131, p=0.71).
